pageData.text: In this investigation, you will use digital manipulatives to balance chemical equations and better understand the <button class='glossary-text'>Law of Conservation of Mass</button>. These tools aid in the visualization of the number of <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button> present on each side of a chemical reaction.

text: Define <button class='glossary-text'>atom</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>element</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>molecule</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>compound</button>.
Apply the use of <button class='glossary-text'>coefficients</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>subscripts</button> to balance chemical equations.
Predict the <button class='glossary-text'>products</button> for simple chemical reactions.

pageData.text: Balancing chemical equations is the application of the <button class='glossary-text'>law of conservation of mass</button>, stating mass is neither created nor destroyed. When it comes to exercise and weight loss, this law still applies. The question of where fat goes when one loses weight was asked of 150 healthcare professionals, such as doctors and dieticians, in a 2014 survey; however, over half the participants held the erroneous view that the missing fat is transformed into energy or heat<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. This notion flies in the face of the law of conservation of mass! So, when you lose weight, where does the fat go?

We can find a clue to this puzzle in the commonly used phrase “burning fat”: the metabolization of fat is a similar reaction to that of combustion in which fuel in the presence of oxygen breaks down into water and carbon dioxide. When you exercise, or simply go about your day, water and carbon dioxide leave the body during exhalation; water also leaves the body through other excretory processes. When you do the math, burning 10 kg of fat requires 29 kg of oxygen to be inhaled and produces 28 kg of carbon dioxide and 11 kg of water<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1UNSWnews. (2014, December 16). When you lose weight, where does the fat go? EurekAlert!
https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/809042

pageData.desc: The torso of a man with his shirt pulled up to expose his midriff. The man holds a tape measure around his waist.
pageData.altText: The torso of a man with his shirt pulled up to expose his midriff. The man holds a tape measure around his waist.

pageData.text: The ability to balance equations is an essential skill in carrying out a chemical reaction. Balanced equations are necessary to determine the amount of <button class='glossary-text'>product</button> that can be produced in a chemical reaction and to ensure that the appropriate amounts of <button class='glossary-text'>reactants</button> are added to allow reactions to occur. A chemical equation is a visual representation of a chemical reaction and is written much like a mathematical equation. Substances (reactants) are combined to produce one or more new substances (product[s]). Instead of the equal sign that would be used in a mathematical equation, an arrow links the left side of the equation, where the reactants are, and the right side of the equation, where the product(s) is, and indicates the direction of the reaction. A simple chemical equation can be written as follows:
A + B → AB

The <button class='glossary-text'>Law of Conservation of Mass</button> states that mass is neither created nor destroyed during ordinary (i.e., nonnuclear) chemical reactions or physical changes. After the introduction of Dalton’s atomic theory, the wording of the law was revised to more specifically state that <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button> are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical reaction. The changes that occur during any reaction are simply rearrangements of the atoms.

An atom is the smallest unit of an that retains the chemical properties of that element. An element is a pure substance that consists of only one type of atom. A is the smallest unit of a that retains the chemical properties of that compound. A compound is a substance that consists of identical molecules composed of two or more elements.

options.text: The smallest unit of an element that retains the chemical properties of that element.
The smallest unit of a compound that retains the chemical properties of that compound.
A pure substance that consists of only one type of atom.
A unit that goes into a chemical reaction.
A unit that is produced by a chemical reaction.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: An element is a pure substance that consists of only one type of atom.

options.text: A visual representation of a chemical reaction.
A pure substance that consists of only one type of element.
A unit in chemistry that indicates how many elements are present.
The smallest unit of an element that retains the chemical properties of that element.
A number placed before the chemical symbol for an element.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: An atom is the smallest unit of an element that retains the chemical properties of that element.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An atom is the smallest unit of an element that retains the chemical properties of that element. An element is a pure substance that consists of only one type of atom. A molecule is the smallest unit of a compound that retains the chemical properties of that compound. A compound is a substance that consists of identical molecules composed of two or more elements.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An atom is the smallest unit of an element that retains the chemical properties of that element. An element is a pure substance that consists of only one type of atom. A molecule is the smallest unit of a compound that retains the chemical properties of that compound. A compound is a substance that consists of identical molecules composed of two or more elements.

pageData.text: The same number of <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button> of each <button class='glossary-text'>element</button> is present before and after a chemical reaction occurs. This is represented by a <button class='glossary-text'>balanced chemical equation</button>. Numbers, called <button class='glossary-text'>coefficients</button>, are placed before the symbol for an element or the formula for a <button class='glossary-text'>compound</button> in a chemical equation. Coefficients indicate the number of <button class='glossary-text'>molecules</button> of a compound, or the number of atoms of an element that is not part of a molecule or compound, present in the reaction. <button class='glossary-text'>Subscripts</button> indicate the number of atoms of a particular element in a molecule.

pageData.question:
Identify the coefficient for carbon dioxide (CO2) in the following balanced equation:
C3H8 + 5 H2 → 4 H2O + 3 CO2

options.text: C

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Numbers, called coefficients, are placed before the symbol for an element or the formula for a compound in a chemical equation.

pageData.question:
How many hydrogen (H) atoms are on the left side of this equation?
C3H8 + 5 H2 → 4 H2O + 3 CO2

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Subscripts indicate the number of atoms of a particular element in a molecule. So, there are eight hydrogen atoms in the first reactant. And although there are only two hydrogen atoms in the second reactant, there are five of these molecules in the balanced reaction; so there are 10 hydrogen atoms from the second reactant for a total of 18 hydrogen atoms on the left side of the equation.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The same number of atoms of each element is present before and after a chemical reaction occurs. This is represented by a balanced chemical equation. Numbers, called coefficients, are placed before the symbol for an element or the formula for a compound in a chemical equation. Coefficients indicate the number of molecules of a compound, or the number of atoms of an element that is not part of a molecule or compound, present in the reaction. Subscripts indicate the number of atoms of a particular element in a molecule.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The same number of atoms of each element is present before and after a chemical reaction occurs. This is represented by a balanced chemical equation. Numbers, called coefficients, are placed before the symbol for an element or the formula for a compound in a chemical equation. Coefficients indicate the number of molecules of a compound, or the number of atoms of an element that is not part of a molecule or compound, present in the reaction. Subscripts indicate the number of atoms of a particular element in a molecule.

pageData.desc: coefficients versus subscripts of a water molecule
pageData.altText: coefficients versus subscripts of a water molecule

pageData.text: A chemical equation in which the number of of each on the left () side of the equation is not equal to the number of atoms of that element on the right () side of the equation is unbalanced. An unbalanced chemical equation does not obey the . In the following example, the number of each type of atom on each side of the equation is counted using tally marks and recorded in Tally Table 1.
H2O + Fe → Fe2O3 + H2

pageData.title: Tally Table 1

pageData.text: For example, if we were to change the in the formula for water (H2O) to “3” (H3O), we would no longer have water—we would have hydronium.

In a <button class='glossary-text'>balanced chemical equation</button>, the number of <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button> of each <button class='glossary-text'>element</button> is the same on the left and right sides of the equation. When a chemical equation is balanced, the <button class='glossary-text'>Law of Conservation of Mass</button> is obeyed. <button class='glossary-text'>Coefficients</button> may be adjusted to balance a chemical equation, but <button class='glossary-text'>subscripts</button>, which are intrinsic to the structure of the <button class='glossary-text'>molecule</button>, must remain unchanged.

The equation is balanced by adjusting coefficients associated with the element or <button class='glossary-text'>compound</button> in a chemical equation. This equation indicates there are three molecules of water present:
3H2O + 2Fe → Fe2O3 + 3H2

One water molecule (H2O) consists of two hydrogen atoms (2H) and one oxygen atom (O), so 3 water molecules would contain 3 × 2 hydrogen atoms and 3 × 1 oxygen atoms. Thus, there are 6 hydrogen atoms and 3 oxygen atoms represented in 3H2O. Note that coefficients, can be changed in order to make an equation balanced. Subscripts, however, cannot be changed to balance the equation because that would change the molecule present.

pageData.title: Tally Table 2

pageData.text: Any change to a coefficient affects the number of atoms of every element in the formula.

pageData.subTitle: Steps for balancing a basic chemical equation
text: Write the unbalanced equation for the reaction. Place the <button class='glossary-text'>reactants</button> on the left side of the arrow and the <button class='glossary-text'>products</button> on the right side of the arrow.

Tally the number of of each on both sides of the equation.
  1. If the same number of atoms of each element appears on both sides of the equation, the formula is balanced. No more steps are necessary.
  2. If the numbers of the atoms are not equal, the must be adjusted to balance the equation.
Starting with atoms that appear in only one substance on each side of the arrow, adjust coefficients for each formula in order to make the number of atoms on both sides equal.
Continue adjusting the coefficients until the number of atoms of each element is the same on both sides of the equation.

pageData.question: What is the first recommended step when balancing a basic chemical equation?

options.text: Remove subscripts from both sides of the chemical equation.
Write the unbalanced equation for the reaction.
Tally the number of atoms of each element on the reactants side of the equation.
Tally the number of atoms of each element on the products side of the equation.
Adjust coefficients on both sides of the chemical equation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The first recommended step when balancing a basic chemical equation is to write the unbalanced equation for the reaction. Place the reactants on the left side of the arrow and the products on the right side of the arrow.

pageData.question: You are balancing a chemical equation in which there are more iron (Fe) atoms on the left side of the equation than on the right side. Which of the following steps will balance the number of iron atoms in the equation?

options.text: Adjust the coefficients in the equation.
Adjust the subscripts in the equation.
Add a new product to the right side of the equation.
Reverse the direction of the arrow in the equation.
Change the chemical symbol in one of the products containing iron.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When balancing a chemical equation, coefficients can be adjusted, subscripts cannot.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Begin balancing a basic chemical equation by writing the unbalanced equation for the reaction. Place the reactants on the left side of the arrow and the products on the right side of the arrow. Then, tally the number of atoms of each element on both sides of the equation. If the same number of atoms of each element appears on both sides of the equation, the reaction is balanced. No more steps are necessary. If the numbers of atoms are not equal, the coefficients must be adjusted to balance the equation. Coefficients, rather than subscripts, are adjusted to obey the law of conservation of mass. Subscripts are intrinsic to the structure of the molecule and therefore must remain unchanged.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Begin balancing a basic chemical equation by writing the unbalanced equation for the reaction. Place the reactants on the left side of the arrow and the products on the right side of the arrow. Then, tally the number of atoms of each element on both sides of the equation. If the same number of atoms of each element appears on both sides of the equation, the reaction is balanced. No more steps are necessary. If the numbers of atoms are not equal, the coefficients must be adjusted to balance the equation. Coefficients, rather than subscripts, are adjusted to obey the law of conservation of mass. Subscripts are intrinsic to the structure of the molecule and therefore must remain unchanged.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: During ordinary chemical reactions, atoms are neither created nor destroyed. What is the name of this law?

options.text: law of conservation of mass
law of conservation of energy
law of conservation of compounds
Newton’s law of conservation
ideal gas law

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best defines a compound?

options.text: two or more types of atoms chemically combined in definite proportions
multiple atoms of the same element combined in definite proportions
multiple atoms of only one type of element
the smallest particle of an element retaining the element’s chemical properties
a portion of a molecule retaining the molecule’s chemical properties

assestmentData.question:
How many copper atoms are needed to balance this equation?
_Cu + O2 --> 2 CuO
How many total molecules are present in “4 C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>”?
What do the numbers in subscript stand for in a chemical formula?

options.text: the number of each atom present
the amount of molecules present
the size of the atom
the charge of the atom
the total number of molecules in a chemical reaction

assestmentData.question:
Water (H2O) in this chemical equation is considered which of the following?
3 H2O + 2 Fe --> Fe2O3 + 3 H2

options.text: a reactant
a product
a coefficient
an atom
an element

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

This simulation will allow you to not only count the number of <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button> to balance a chemical equation, but also build the <button class='glossary-text'>molecules</button> involved in the reaction. The simulation can be found after the protocol for the activity.
Select the chemical formula for the <button class='glossary-text'>molecule</button> you wish to build from the buttons on the left side of the workbench.
Drag the correct <button class='glossary-text'>atoms</button> to the template of the molecule. Then drag the finished molecule into the box under its chemical formula in the equation.
Repeat Steps 1-2 for the remaining molecules in the equation.

Select the "Tally Table" button at the bottom of the window. Count the atoms of each <button class='glossary-text'>element</button> on both sides of the equation. Record your counts in the tally table.
For each element, if the number of atoms is the same on both sides, go to Step 8.

Adjust the <button class='glossary-text'>coefficients</button> in the equation at the top of the window to change the number of molecules reacting in the equation. The number of molecules in the box changes accordingly. Re-count the atoms of each element as you change the coefficients and adjust your tally table data.
Repeat Step 6 until the number of atoms of each element are the same on both sides of the equation.
Take a screenshot of your results and upload the image to the Lab Notebook.  Then, select the “Submit" button at the bottom of your tally table to continue to another equation.

If your instructor asks you to complete multiple equations, select the "Next Equation" button from the menu when it appears. Be sure to refer to your instructor's directions as to how many of the five possible equations you are to complete.
If you have completed your required number of equations, or all equations have been completed, select the "Finish" button from the menu to conclude the simulation.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

data.title: Atom
data.content: The smallest unit of an element that retains the chemical properties of that element

data.title: Balanced chemical equation
data.content: The number of atoms of each element is the same on the left and right sides of the equation

data.title: Coefficients
data.content: Number placed before the symbol for an element or the formula for a compound in a chemical equation

data.title: Compound
data.content: A substance that consists of identical molecules composed of two or more elements

data.title: Element
data.content: A pure substance that consists of only one type of atom

data.title: Law of Conservation of Mass
data.content: States that atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical reaction; the changes that occur during any reaction are simply rearrangements of the atoms

data.title: Molecule
data.content: The smallest unit of a compound that retains the chemical properties of that compound

data.title: Product
data.content: A substance produced in a chemical reaction

data.title: Reactants
data.content: Substances consumed in a chemical reaction to generate product

data.title: Subscripts
data.content: Numbers that indicate the number of atoms of a particular element in a molecule
